blog.description: President Obama will soon be sworn into office, and whether you voted for him or not, he's everybody's president. What do you want him to remember in his second term? We will feature your responses in our inauguration coverage!
blog.title: Dear Mr. President
blog.name: inauguration2013

posts.caption:
Dear Mr. President,

I voted for you.

I voted for you again for two reasons: My grandfather told me that if you don’t vote, you can’t complain. And two, I believe Presidents need two terms to fully realize their goals.

Please cut military spending, it is out of control. My future, as well as many of my peers, depends on the nation’s ability to pay its bills, and reducing the military budget is a good start.

Please make the tough decisions, the moral ones. You are in a lame duck term now so there is no need to worry about being re-elected. Leave a better legacy than what has all ready come to pass: Affordable Health care, although not perfect, is a good start, but it is tainted with drone attacks.

These matter because I am 23 and I have to live with what happens. I voted for you again because hope/ wish/ believe you truley have my generation’s interest in mind. Please don’t make me more cynical that I already am.

Signed,
Vincent Kolb-Lugo from A Coruña, Spain

Dear Mr. President,

I voted for you.

In 2008, I voted for you. In 2012, I did not.

Coming off the Bush years, I was enamored with your platform of transparency in 2008, and then you invoked executive privilege to sequester documentation regarding an active and public investigation into Fast and Furious, and successfully subverted the public. There was one person fired for this operation during your first term and ironically that was the whistleblower.

If I were to fail in my responsibilities for my job I would understandably be fired, and my failures are not fatal. I should hope in your second term that the people in your employ who have certain responsibilities delegated beneath them will be held accountable when they fail to perform their duties responsibly and effectively. That didn’t happen in your first term. The deliberate inaction to hold accountable those who are is called cronyism. End it.

Signed,
Michael from Orange, CA

Dear Mr. President,

I’d rather not say how I voted.

A nation of broken hearts loves you, and we admire you for your utterly human reaction and leadership in this most personal disaster.And now we go about transforming national grief through change.This is my son. I am bound and determined to protect his mind as well as his body. He will learn to hunt. Perhaps shoot a pistol. He will never own, nor will he want to own, an assault weapon while I breathe on this earth. He’s more man at 4 years old than any of the soulless morally bankrupt gun fetishists who have co-opted the 2nd amendment for too long. I thank you Mr. President.

Signed,
Colette from NYC

Dear Mr. President,

I voted for you.

I want the United States of American to to sign onto and ratify the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights.

As a student of Human Rights Studies at your alma mater, my research area is on the right to food. It is currently estimated that 11.1% of US households are considered food insecure and over 868 million people globally suffer from malnutrition (FAO, 2012). In fact, millions of children die each year because they do not have enough food to eat. Therefore, I want you to make it your mission to ensure the right to food to all citizens, both here and abroad. In case you were wondering, this basic human right has three criterion: availability, accessibility and adequacy of food.

Please allow the US to step down from its exceptionalsim, and pledge to be a part of the international community by signing onto the ICESCR.
…..


Imagine there’s no heaven
It’s easy if you try
No hell below us
Above us only sky
Imagine all the people
Living for today…

Imagine there’s no countries
It isn’t hard to do
Nothing to kill or die for
And no religion too
Imagine all the people
Living life in peace…

You may say I’m a dreamer
But I’m not the only one
I hope someday you’ll join us
And the world will be as one

Imagine no possessions
I wonder if you can
No need for greed or hunger
A brotherhood of man
Imagine all the people
Sharing all the world…

You may say I’m a dreamer
But I’m not the only one
I hope someday you’ll join us
And the world will live as one

Signed,
Christine Klotz from New York, New York

Dear Mr. President,

I voted for you.

I started working at 16 and retired at 69. I paid into Social Security and Medicare as an investment. The Social Security trust fund has been stolen. Why? To fight wars? Please remember these two programs are not socialistic gifts to seniors — we worked for them! Please protect them and allow us to care for ourselves! Thank you.

Signed,
Judy Zoldowski from Charlotte, NC

Dear Mr. President,

I didn’t vote for you.

Becuase I am an American Citizen, who’s Family Came Here Legally! Who’s Family Fought For This Country and Died For This Country!

Signed,
Patrick from Massachusetts

Dear Mr. President,

I voted for you.

Dear Mr. President,

Thank you for giving me hope! When I graduated with my Master’s of Science in the the Bush era, I couldn’t get hired because I was over qualified. Since you became president, I have moved a total of 12 times, but have always been able to find work in the federal government. It took five years, but finally I have health insurance, a stable job, and am contributing to retirement.
During the next four years, please remember that it’s not the supervisors or managers that do the majority of work in the government. It’s all of us technicians who clean the toilets in the National Parks, spray invasive weeds, or conduct research. We rely on grant dollars and what little government money is in our bosses budget. We are the first ones to be denied cost-of-living increases, benefits, and the first ones laid off. If Americans want their standards of living to remain the same, or improve, then we need more funding and more employees.

Signed,
Cole D. Provence from Corvallis, OR

Dear Mr. President,

I voted for you.

Now is the time to act on climate change. My little brother needs a meaningful job, we can make turbines in Michigan. Hurricane Sandy costs the country bazillions of dollars, and the scientific community has commented that the severity of that storm isn’t unrelated to climate change. Also, you’re awesome, just keep doing what you’re doing - just turn it up a notch.

Signed,
DR from San Francisco (Montreal for Ph.D.)

Dear Mr. President,

I didn’t vote for you.

Please stop funding the murder of children in the womb with our tax dollars.

Signed,
mjs from Germantown Tn
